newsitem.title: GERMANY: German forwarders plan 1.9-2.5pct road rates hike.
newsitem.headline: German forwarders plan 1.9-2.5pct road rates hike.

text.p: German freight forwarders have been recommended to raise prices from February 1 to stop a slump in market rates, forwarders association BSL said.
The BSL has recommended rises of 1.9 percent in house-to-collection point "client rates" and of 2.5 percent for collection point to door "house freight" prices.
The price hike would apply to groupage services by road but not to air or sea cargo rates, the association noted.
The "client rate" refers to the cost of transport from a shipper's premises to an agreed collection point.
The "house freight" rate covers final delivery to the recipient, which is generally but not always carried out by the forwarder and is thus charged separately.
A BSL spokeswoman said: "There is a massive price war on the market, falling prices and an explosion in fuel costs. We want to go against this ruinous price competition."
Forwarders saw these "moderate" rises as the only solution to their difficult economic situation, she added.
The house freight rate was being increased by slightly more than the client rate to take account of the higher fuel costs generated by city transport, the spokeswoman noted.
Market rates for road transport services in Germany have fallen substantially since fixed tariffs were dropped on January 1, 1994, industry observers noted.
It was unclear how many forwarders would follow the price recommendations in practice given this market pressure, they pointed out.
The price recommendations will go to industry associations for comment and then to the German cartel office before they can be introduced.
